Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Coexistence and Cooperation in Future Spectrum Sharing Heterogeneous Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The world has witnessed an exponential growth in the number and demand of wireless devices, and an increase in the array of wireless broadband network applications that has permeated virtually all aspects of our daily lives. However, this progress cannot be sustained with the current wireless communication network technologies, and this fact has spurred research innovations towards the next generation of wireless systems, typically termed 5G technologies. Two key paradigm shifts that will help meet these demands in 5G networks are the deployment of heterogeneous small cell networks combined with device to device and multi-hop wireless communication, and the adoption of more innovative ways of sharing the spectrum through cognitive radio and dynamic spectrum access.

This project provides tools for quantifying the design trade-offs in future spectrum-agile heterogeneous networks, as well as the theoretical performance limits. Several networks are expected to exist in the same geographical area, each with varying access rules and access protocols. The project studies co-existence and possible cooperation between such networks. Two modes of cooperation are considered: relay cooperation and content cooperation. Two approaches are considered for the analysis of each of these modes, which compose the two thrusts of the proposal: Thrust I: queuing network approaches, which characterize finite as well as asymptotic performance, and focus on random-access based schemes; and Thrust II: scheduling and optimization approaches, which characterize the theoretical best possible performance. The broader impacts of the work include the development of course projects and modules for two graduate level courses that integrate results from the two thrusts of this research, K-12 outreach, enhancement of student diversity and increase of number of women and under-represented groups in engineering, and international collaboration that offers international exposure for students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exponential growth in the number and demand of wireless devices is expected to continue. This growth has motivated two paradigm shifts in the design of wireless networks. First, it has challenged the traditional (macro) cellular network architecture. Future (“5G” and beyond) network designs are now considering small and hybrid cells, called micro, pico, or femto-cells, which may be viewed as base stations with smaller coverage area and coverage capacity, but in general are lower in cost and more randomly distributed/maintained. This new architectural vision is typically called heterogeneous networks or HetNets. Second, the exponential growth has led to new spectrum sharing regulatory rules allowing real-time sharing of licensed but unused spectrum, and new proposals for dynamic spectrum sharing that leverage the advances in software/cognitive radio technologies, promising to provide better spectrum utilization/agility.

 In this context of future heterogeneous network architectures (HetNets, 5G and beyond) that possess spectrum-agile functionalities, this project provided tools for quantifying the design trade-offs in future coexisting and possibly cooperative networks, as well as the theoretical performance limits. We envision the existence of several networks within the same geographical area. Each of these networks may run their own protocols. In addition, the networks may have different priorities in accessing the wireless spectrum, and the regulatory rules about sharing may vary, such as for example a “primary” and a “secondary” network. Furthermore, we relaxed the traditional assumption in which a primary network has unlimited access to the spectrum while a secondary network may access the remaining spectrum only opportunistically. Rather than this traditional view of primary/secondary, we considered that multiple networks may exist with various access rules. In addition to cooperation within networks, we also explore the potential benefits if nodes belonging to different networks are also allowed to cooperate. Thus, we study coexistence as well as cooperation. Coexistence refers to the study of the effect of networks that have different spectrum access priorities, such as for example a network of licensed (primary) users co-exiting with a network of opportunistic unlicensed (secondary) users, on each other. On the other hand, cooperation between different networks may be allowed. Two modes of cooperation are considered; relay cooperation and (cached) content cooperation. In relay cooperation, users of one network may offer to relay the traffic of the other network, in return for a better opportunity to access the spectrum. In content cooperation, users of one network offer to provide (cached) content (if available) to the users of the other network, also in return for a better opportunity to access the spectrum. Compared to prior work, the results here consider new mathematical models that apply to cognitive heterogeneous multi-hop wireless networks (HetNets) with and without cooperation between networks. We proposed and studied new modes of coexistence and cooperation between multi-operator networks: network-layer relay cooperation and content-sharing cooperation. Results of this work include: spectrum sharing in 3-Tier layered architectures, smart contract design, cooperative content caching, delivery, and privacy, opportunistic relaying, and cooperative relaying/caching in future smart vehicular/transportation networks. The results were disseminated through publications in top tier conferences and archival journals exceeding a total of twenty peer-reviewed publications.

 The research results and activities were well integrated with education and outreach activities. For education, the PI developed a new unique Internetworking of Things (IoT) course and associated laboratory at RPI, which adopts a hands-on approach in teaching. For outreach, the project involved six undergraduate students, two from under-represented groups, in research and outreach. This included an activity for these students to mentor, with assistance from the PI, high-school students from a local high-school district with a large number of students from under-represented and economically challenged groups. An after-school club was set-up and run in the Spring or two consecutive years at the high school. The project included international collaborations with collaborators in Finland. It contributed to the new business concept of a “micro-operator” which may have positive impact on the wireless network operators eco-system. Collaborations and joint publications with industry collaborators will also help transfer the results from basic research to technology transfer into market adoption. The project also contributed to human resources and training of seven PhD students (five graduated and two ongoing).
